text:
Morning, Im considering adding GPS as an input to my already successful strategies to enhance them, or as separate strategies in their own right (for comparison etc)
To those of you who are already using GPS data, would you considered this data as ‘nice to have’ or as paramount to your strategies?
The thing that bothers me is just how accurate that info is and seeing screen shots like Liam’s yesterday.
I’d welcome any thoughts and views that anyone has using this feed; thanks in advance (maybe reply in thread to keep the replies together thanks)

text: The data is tricky, your focus should be on validating its accuracy and safe guards when it goes wrong. I personally separate my strategies but log position for both. However in a view to restrict market capacity issues haven't let my normal strategies be impacted too much by the data

However in a view to restrict market capacity issues haven't let my normal strategies be impacted too much by the data

text: The data has serious issues but it’s still possible to make very good money out of it. So :man-shrugging:

text: Quite interesting that you say it has serious data issues - the way their promo text reads on their website is that it's the most advanced thing on the planet

elements.text: Quite interesting that you say it has serious data issues - the way their promo text reads on their website is that it's the most advanced thing on the planet

text:
<@UQL0QDEKA> it took me 3 months to go from having access to the data to running a strategy at test stakes and you know what my level of experience and time commitment is like.

But I was coming from a cold start with no existing horse racing strategies - either in running or pre-event - so that may help you get going faster. 

A very important point that anyone starting now should consider is that the historically available GPS data undergoes some significant transformations from what you would have received live which seriously limits its usefulness for back testing. Guys like <@U4H19D1D2> who have been doing this from the start and collected their own data are in a much better position in this regard. 

You definitely have to account for trackers on the wrong horse, horses running without trackers, seriously miscalibrated trackers (horse running outside the track, starts the race 10m behind the stalls, appears to be leading when is actually in second place, etc)

text: Thanks <@UBS7QANF3> <@U4H19D1D2> for the insights. Very interesting. Im just i the process of having a back testing system created and was thinking of adding this to the mix. I have a slightly different approach in that I haven’t (to date) used back testing nor data science in the formation of any of my in play strategies, which are based on the price action in play. This has stood the test of time over the last 14 years or so. As Im at my desk most days business hours, Ive watched the price action on a separate monitor to the one I use in my day job for tens of thousands races and I have a very strong hunch of something Id like to explore further via data analysis and I was wondering how the GPS data is contributing to the factor. I appreciate that the price action Im using is at least 1 second behind those of you using the GPS data, so not ideal and Im thinking “What if…“Anyway many thanks for the replies gents, food for thought

I appreciate that the price action Im using is at least 1 second behind those of you using the GPS data, so not ideal and Im thinking “What if…“Anyway many thanks for the replies gents, food for thought

text: The data is useful but as others have mentioned, there are sometimes some hideous inaccuracies in it. I do think that the data provides many possible angles of attack but there are many issues to be aware of. I have come across many banana skins and dodgy happenings, but this slack group has been so useful in that regard with the more experienced users basically explaining that these things are "the norm". Biggest problem I have found is identifying anyone who actually DOES use it. Again this slack has been excellent in that regard when something goes wrong at least you can confirm that others are seeing the same rather than it being your own code that is at fault. I would say that if you are expecting highly accurate positional data you will be disappointed BUT it is still very useful. From a profit point of view it has helped me deal with no income after I lost my job at the end of May. It is safe to say that I would be very close to the bottom of the food chain in terms of the GPS players here but even I am making it pay.

text: I should probably add <@UQL0QDEKA> that I am most likey using the least advanced setup and least optimal execution. My stuff is currently running inside a Qt GUI application running on Linux on my home desktop with CPU time wasted on such frivolous things as a real time GPS render tool and other unecessary things. Once I make the switch to headless running on AWS or similar I would be hoping that the profitability increases as there are SO many optimisations to potentially make.

text: <@U011VL3CA2Y> Assuming a tight market spread there is always equal value on both sides of the book - it can't be otherwise. However that doesn't mean it's evenly spread, so you could have 5% back edge on one runner but the balancing edge spread thinly across the others. If you're only going for bets above X value then you could end up with only one bet - or always lay bets or whatever. When you think about it; that's what you should expect in a market with several selections - like a horse race, but it should never occur in a 2 selection market like a tennis match.  Whether what you'r finding is normal depends on what kind of market you're betting on and how you're generating your prices.

elements.text: Assuming a tight market spread there is always equal value on both sides of the book - it can't be otherwise. However that doesn't mean it's evenly spread, so you could have 5% back edge on one runner but the balancing edge spread thinly across the others. If you're only going for bets above X value then you could end up with only one bet - or always lay bets or whatever. When you think about it; that's what you should expect in a market with several selections - like a horse race, but it should never occur in a 2 selection market like a tennis match.  Whether what you'r finding is normal depends on what kind of market you're betting on and how you're generating your prices.

text: why should there be equal value on both sides of the book? if the "true underlying probability" is p, and there is value in the back side, this means there cannot be value on the lay side, doesn't it? the fact that there is value on the back side, implies that the one who is laying that bet, is loosing

elements.text: why should there be equal value on both sides of the book? if the "true underlying probability" is p, and there is value in the back side, this means there cannot be value on the lay side, doesn't it? the fact that there is value on the back side, implies that the one who is laying that bet, is loosing

text: assuming, as you said, a tight market spread so that best back price ~= best lay price

elements.text: assuming, as you said, a tight market spread so that best back price ~= best lay price

text: I think he meant that in a tight spread, 'p' is in the middle of the spread, i.e. >ATB and <ATL.

elements.text: I think he meant that in a tight spread, 'p' is in the middle of the spread, i.e. >ATB and <ATL.

text: Sorry; I didn't explain well - that's not what I meant. I'm talking about the market as a whole. The probability of all possible outcomes must sum to 1 (or 100% if you like) and so must the book (1/all prices). So if one selection is overly short then others must be too long. Ergo: assuming tight price spreads there is always as much edge available to lay as to back - but like I said it can be distributed or focused in any number of ways. Your initial assumption was that back and lay value should be equally available, basic maths tells us that that must be true. However for the reason I explained above that doesn't necessarily mean that you'll get equal opportunities to bet.
